There are three kinds of precepts.
What are the three?
The first is the cowherd's precepts, the second is the Nirgrantha's precepts, and the third is the noble eight-fold precepts.
Householder's wife!
What is called the cowherd's precepts?
If a cowherd in the morning lets the cows out to graze in the fields, and in the evening drives them back to the village, when they return to the village, he thinks like this:
'Today I let the cows out to graze in this place, tomorrow I will let them out to graze in that place.
Today I drink the cows here, tomorrow I will drink them there.
Today my cows stay here to rest, tomorrow they will stay there to rest.' Householder's wife!
If a person like this observes the precepts, he thinks like this:
'Today I ate such food, tomorrow I will eat such food.ğŸ”½Today I drank such drink, tomorrow I will drink such drink.
Today I digested such food, tomorrow I will digest such food.'
That person spends the day and night attached to desires here, this is called the cowherd's fast.
If one observes the fast in this way, it is the cowherd's fast, which does not bring great benefit, great fruit, great merit, or widespread practice.
Householder's wife!
What is called the Nirgrantha fast?
If there are those who have gone forth to study the Nirgranthas, they would advise people, saying:

'If there are beings outside of the east, a hundred yojanas away, protect them, and abandon weapons and sticks. If there are beings outside of the south, west, and north, a hundred yojanas away, protect them, and abandon weapons and sticks. This is encouraging others.
Some protect beings with thoughts, some protect beings without thoughts. On the fifteenth day, when you recite the Pratimoká¹£a, take off your clothes, stand naked facing east, and say:
'I have no parents, I am not a parent. I have no wife and children, I am not a wife or child. I have no slaves, I am not a slave.'
Householder's wife!
If they want to encourage true words, they encourage false words instead. That person sees their parents every day and thinks:
'They are my parents.'
The parents see their child every day and also think:ğŸ”½'This is my child.'
'This is my son.'

'This is my wife and children.'

'This is our master.'
When they see the slaves, they think:
'These are my slaves.'
The slaves, seeing them, also think:
'These are our masters.'
They use this desire, using it without giving, not using it by giving. This is called the Nigantha fast.
If one observes the Nigantha fast in this way, one will not attain great benefit, great fruit, great merit, or widespread [renown].
Householder's wife!
What is called the noble eight-part fast?
When the well-versed noble disciple observes the fast, they think like this:

'The Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, for his whole life abstains from killing, abandons killing, puts aside sticks and swords, is conscientious and kind, and benefits all beings, even insects. He purifies his mind regarding killing. I too, for my whole life, abstain from killing, abandon killing, put aside sticks and swords, am conscientious and kind, and benefit all beings, even insects.
I now purify my mind regarding killing. By this factor, I am equal to the Arhat, without distinction.'
Therefore, it is called the observance.
Furthermore, householder's wife!
When the learned noble disciple observes the observance, he thinks like this:

'The Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, for his whole life abstains from taking what is not given, abandons taking what is not given, takes only what is given, delights in taking only what is given, always takes pleasure in giving and sharing, his mind is open and free with regard to his property, he does not expect to be repaid, and he does not harbor thoughts of theft. He is able to restrain himself.

He purifies his mind with regard to taking what is not given. I too, for my whole life, will abstain from taking what is not given, abandon taking what is not given, take only what is given, delight in taking only what is given, always take pleasure in giving and sharing, my mind will be open and free with regard to my property, I will not expect to be repaid, and I will not harbor thoughts of theft. I will be able to restrain myself.
I purify my mind with regard to taking what is not given. In this respect, I am equal to the Arhat, without distinction.'
Thus it is called the observance.
Furthermore, householder's wife!
When the learned noble disciple observes the observance, he thinks like this:

'The Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, for his whole life, abstains from sexual misconduct, abandons sexual misconduct, practices celibacy, is pure, without blemish, free from sexual activity, and has abandoned lust.

He purifies his mind regarding sexual misconduct. I, on this day and night, abstain from sexual misconduct, abandon sexual misconduct, practice celibacy, am pure, without blemish, free from sexual activity, and have abandoned lust.
I purify my mind regarding sexual misconduct. In this respect, I am equal to the Arhat, without distinction.'
Thus it is called the observance.
Furthermore, householder's wife!
When the well-versed noble disciple observes the observance, he should think like this:

'The Arhat, the Perfectly Enlightened One, for his whole life, abstains from false speech, abandons false speech, speaks the truth, delights in the truth, abides in the truth, is trustworthy, and does not deceive the world.

They purify their minds regarding false speech. I too, for as long as I live, will refrain from false speech and abandon false speech. I will speak the truth and delight in the truth, abide in the truth, and be trustworthy. I will not deceive the world.
I purify my mind regarding false speech. By this factor, I am equal to the Worthy Ones and do not differ.

If the learned noble disciple, when observing the observance, thinks like this:
'The Worthy Ones, the Truly Awakened Ones, for as long as they live, abandon intoxicants that cause heedlessness and cut off intoxicants that cause heedlessness.
They purify their minds regarding intoxicants that cause heedlessness. I too, for as long as I live, will abandon intoxicants that cause heedlessness and cut off intoxicants that cause heedlessness.
I purify my mind regarding intoxicants that cause heedlessness. By this factor, I am equal to the Worthy Ones and do not differ.'

Furthermore, householder's wife!
When the well-versed noble disciple observes the precepts, they should think like this:
'The Arhats, the Truly Awakened Ones, throughout their lives abandon high and wide beds, cut off high and wide beds, delighting in sitting and lying on low beds or mats.
They purify their minds regarding high and wide beds. On this day and night, I also abandon high and wide beds, cut off high and wide beds, delighting in sitting and lying on low beds or mats.
